intro: Lupinus intermontanus, commonly known as the mountain lupine, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its upright growth habit and showy blue to purple flowers. The plant has compound leaves with small, oval-shaped leaflets and produces cylindrical seed pods that contain several seeds. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in open areas such as meadows and rocky slopes. Lupinus intermontanus plays an important role in ecological systems by fixing nitrogen in the soil, benefiting surrounding plant life.
